SUMMARY: Betaine inhibitor, BetI, acts as a repressor of glycine betaine synsis from choline [8626294]. It is negatively autoregulated and coordinately represses transcription of choline transporter and operon related to synsis of glycine betaine. se divergent operons are expressed only under aerobic conditions and are induced by osmotic stress [1956285]. BetI is an unusual repressor because it remains bound to DNA during induction. BetI forms a complex with DNA in presence of choline, binding to a 20-bp-long sequence with dyad symmetry that overlaps betTp and betIp simultaneously [8626295]. position of repressor gene within operon is unusual too, as regulatory genes tend to be positioned at end of operons and this gene is located at beginning of operon. BetI belongs to TetR/AcrR family of transcriptional regulators [8626295, 1956285]. This protein composed of two domains, an amino-terminal domain that contains a potential helix-turn-helix DNA-binding motif and a carboxy-terminal domain involved in co-inducer recognition and dimerization [1956285].
